title.narrative: WHO - Strengthening Health Security in Gaza: Support to the Public Health Laboratory

description.narrative: WHO will support the health authorities in Gaza with rehabilitation of the public health lab, and provide expert training for health staff. The public health laboratory in Gaza will strengthen the health sector’s capacity to deal with future epidemics and infectious diseases. Covid-19 has strongly emphasised the need for this capacity in every country. The WHO has strong competency in this field. The NIPH can assist with technical expertise to ensure the project is completed to a high standard. Public health is a priority for Norway in Palestine.

title.narrative: West Bank Emergency Social Protection COVID-19 Response Project

description.narrative: This project supports the Palestinian Authority’s emergency response to the COVID-19 crisis by providing cash support and short temporary employment opportunities to Palestinians living in the West Bank through an Emergency Cash Transfers (CTP) and a Cash for Work (C4W) mechanism respectively. The support will be funding the World Bank (WB) ‘West Bank Emergency Social Protection COVID-19 Response Project’ that was approved by the WB board on 23 July 2020 for a total project cost of USD 30,0 million. The Norwegian support will be used to replenish the trust funds to expand and scale up the activities.

participating-org.narrative: Norwegian Ministry of Foreign Affairs - Embassies

provider-org.narrative: Norwegian Ministry of Foreign Affairs - Embassies
Norwegian Ministry of Foreign Affairs - Embassies

title.narrative: PAL-20/0018 - West Bank Emergency Social Protection COVID-19 Response Project

reporting-org.narrative: Norad - Norwegian Agency for Development Cooperation

title.narrative: UNRWA Support to COVID-19 respons

description.narrative:
Since the start of the crisis, the Agency has worked diligently to deliver essential lifesaving services to Palestine refugees throughout the Middle East. Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) has been distributed to thousands of front line health staff, triage systems have been introduced in all health centres to screen patients with respiratory symptoms and minimize contact with other patients, non-critical health services have been suspended, and telemedicine and door-to-door delivery of medicine and food were introduced to reduce foot traffic at health clinics and food distribution centres. The direct target group of the project Palestine Refugees in the West Bank and Gaza, residents of refugee camps, health staff and school children. The planned intervention aims to support UNRWA to fulfil its needs to hire additional health staff, including medical officers, practical nurses, pharmacists, midwives, lab technicians and cleaners for a period ranging from 1-3 months in order to contain COVID-19 situation in the West Bank and Gaza.
- Approx. 178 surge health staff hired to support UNRWA’s Covid-19 response. - UNRWA schools are provided with needed cleaning and disinfection materials & tools - A staff rotation system is in place in all 43 health centers in the West Bank as part of COVID-19 response. - UNRWA students receive equitable, quality and inclusive education services while standards of physical distancing are enforced. - Refugee camps benefit from improved access to sanitation services and infection control measures.

participating-org.narrative: Norwegian Ministry of Foreign Affairs - Embassies
UNRWA - UN Relief and Works Agency
UNRWA - UN Relief and Works Agency

provider-org.narrative: Norwegian Ministry of Foreign Affairs - Embassies
Norwegian Ministry of Foreign Affairs - Embassies

title.narrative: PAL-20/0019 - UNRWA Support to COVID-19 respons

reporting-org.narrative: Norad - Norwegian Agency for Development Cooperation

title.narrative: Roots of Health - Supporting Women and Young People's Access to Sexual and Reproductive Health Rights

description.narrative: This project will empower and support women and young people in Palawan to realize their sexual and reproductive health rights in the midst and aftermath of the COVID-19 crisis. The project will have three main components: 1) Provide access to services - Restore and strengthen access to sexual and reproductive health services, including pre-and post-natal care and HIV screening through their clinics and community outreach to Puerto Princesa’s Barangay Health Centers. 2) Improve health communication - Mobilize women at the community level to ensure that public health education messages on risk and prevention strategies for COVID-19, reproductive health and general health are reaching all women and young people 3) Strengthen women’s leadership - Strengthen the leadership and meaningful participation of women in decision-making processes in addressing the COVID-19 outbreak by training and empowering one Community Health Advocate (CHA) in each of the barangays Roots of Health support. Roots of Health (ROH) has been supporting sexual and reproductive health rights in Palawan for the last 10 and a half years and they are well-placed now to provide support to the City Health Office to ensure that women and young people can continue to access essential reproductive health care services during and beyond the health crisis brought on by the coronavirus.

participating-org.narrative: Norwegian Ministry of Foreign Affairs - Embassies

title.narrative: UN System-Wide Evaluation for Collective UN Accountability and Learning on COVID-19

description.narrative: The project is to support a coherent System-Wide Evaluation of COVID- for gathering evaluative evidence on (a) how the UN is contributing collectively to reversing the challenges brought by COVID-19 in the first year of the decade of action for SDGs, and (b) providing credible evaluative evidence on progress, innovation, good practices and lessons learned. The project support system wide management response and action to the evaluation recommendations. The design of the evaluation leverages the COVID -19 Response and Recovery fund to learn lessons and report progress of UN contribution as a whole. The approach of the proposals is in line with the UN development reform and the Funding Compact.

title.narrative: Global Thematic Fund for Health Covid-19

description.narrative:
Support to Covid-19 through Unicefs global thematic fund for health
Covid is having a serious impact on children and households - causing reduced use of health services, less access to school and increased household poverty and malnutrition. The impacts on children and women are significant. UNICEF has a multi pronged approach to supporting countries and communities to implement covid responses. Unicef is involved form global to local - and across key sectors.

title.narrative: Mali, Unicef thematic fund for health Covid-19

description.narrative: Earmarked contribution to Covid-19 health response in Mali - negotiated at country level between embassy and UNICEF. Mali has suffered a coup - is in the midst of civil strife and massive climate degradation. On top of thes epressures the covid 19 response is presenting major challenges. UNICEF works across sectors to support women and children. Norway supports health and nutrition as well as education via seperate agreements.

title.narrative: CIC 2020 - Effective cooperation across the HDP nexus in the context of COVID-19

description.narrative: This project will expand on CIC's work supporting the UN and its partners to prevent and address protracted crises by engaging more effectively across the HDP nexus in fragile and at-risk countries. The project will aim to generate practical ideas to strengthen HDP linkages in a range of contexts and to operationalize conflict prevention more effectively. The project's activities will be in East Africa, West Africa, Sahel, Middle East/North Africa, New York, Geneva, Oslo, and TBD.

title.narrative: Pre-project Phase to Developing a Digital Approach to Ensure Inclusive Education Delivery

description.narrative: The aim of this initiative is to leverage new and readily available digital technologies to enhance outreach and quality of education services in ASEAN CLMV countries to offset the negative implication of social distancing and non-access to physical education services as result of the COVID-19 pandemic. The Project has two phases: a Pre-Project with the objective to specify the structure (including potential methodology and partners), scope and deliverables of the project; and Phase 2 (the Main Project) where the concept is developed and implemented in accordance with the specification of the Pre-Project.

title.narrative: Support to Migrants and local communities in SRB, MAK and MNE

description.narrative:
Support to Migrants and Local Communities in Montengro, North Macedonia and Serbia. The project intends to provide comprehensive, well-planned and tailor-made subgranting support to a number of communities in Serbia, Montenegro and North Macedonia. In addition, it will include extensive and relevant capacity-building efforts as well as the evidence-based advocacy initiatives in the area of forced migration.
Due to Covid-19 pandemics, subgranting support was extended to benefit all vulnerable groups.

The project will ensure badly needed working capital to SMEs in the region following the Covid 19 crisis.

title.narrative: Bilateral programmme with Serbia

description.narrative:
Bilateral cooperation with Serbia. Individual projects will be granted after agreed procedures of call for proposals and joint assessment.
In 2020, unused 767.040 NOK were reprogrammed and used for project: Response to Covid-19 crisis in Serbia implemented by UNDP with Ministry of Interior as the final beneficiary. This consists of procurement of materials and supplies urgently needed to suppress transmission, stop the pandemic and support to counter Covid-19 crisis to the Government of Serbia.

title.narrative: Support to UN Emergency Appeal for Response to COVID-19 and its impact

description.narrative:
This UN coordinated emergency appeal calls for $316.4 million to respond to the immediate COVID-19 public health response and the most urgent needs generated by the secondary consequences caused by the COVID-19 outbreak for the most vulnerable Ugandans. The appeal prioritizes the most urgent interventions to be carried out in Uganda in the next six months (April to September 2020) in support of the Government-led response to COVID-19. Complementing the Government of Uganda and the Ministry of Health’s response, the appeal focuses on: 1) the immediate public health response to COVID-19, and 2) response to the secondary impacts of the pandemic on vulnerable Ugandans, including children, the elderly, women, people living with disabilities, people living with HIV, refugees, migrants, and those displaced by natural disasters.
The appeal targets at risk communities across Uganda under five core themes: 1) Life-Saving Health Services, including the immediate COVID-19 public health response; 2) Food Security, Livelihoods and Nutrition; 3) Social Protection and Life-Saving Essential Services; 4) Refugees and Displacement; and 5) Immediate Economic Support & Digital Innovation. Under each theme, the Appeal presents two sets of time-bound interventions, as follows: 1. The most urgently required immediate interventions for the public health emergency and impacts from COVID-19 in next eight weeks are prioritized and highlighted; 2. These are placed alongside priority interventions that will tackle long-term public health interventions aimed at containment of COVID-19 and address the impacts of the containment measures over the next six months. The appeal targets 12.8 million people in need.

title.narrative: Supporting preparedness, mitigation and response to the primary and secondary impacts of COVID-19 on IDP and vulnerable populations in Yemen

description.narrative: Given the context of COVID-19, combined with the already dire humanitarian needs in Yemen, our approach aims to prevent, mitigate and respond to COVID-19: in the immediate/short-term by providing life-saving assistance through targeted and coordinated activities in WASH, protection, and cash to IDP and vulnerable populations. The programme will provide an integrated, package across two governorates; Hodeidah and Taizz.

reporting-org.narrative: The Leprosy Mission Nepal

title.narrative: Leveraging leprosy infrastructure to strengthen the COVID19 response

description.narrative: The Project will increase the preparedness of Anandaban Hospital to deliver critical COVID-19 care to patients experiencing COVID-19 complications including vulnerable individuals including people affected by leprosy and disabilities and to protect the most vulnerable and health workers from infection. The project will do this by training all staff in COVID-19 response including testing, treating, and managing cases; opening an isolation ward aimed to treat critical patients using ventilators and respirators; providing counselling sessions for both staff and patients struggling with their experience of COVID-19; sharing awareness-raising messages about how to keep safe during the pandemic; and by distributing food and sanitation packages amongst households in the local community.

title.narrative: Occupied Palestinian Territories :Explosive Ordnance Risk Education

description.narrative: The Activity will support efforts to reduce the risk of harm from explosive hazards in the West Bank of the Occupied Palestinian Territories through (1) enabling the Palestinian Mine Action Center to deliver Explosive Ordnance risk education (EORE) in the West Bank, (2) training trainers to continue providing EORE, and (3) institutional strengthening of the PMAC. WHO messaging on hand washing and social distancing will be incorporated to minimise risk of spreading COVID during or after training.

title.narrative: Covid-19 - 2020 Tonga Immediate Health Systems Preparedness Activity

description.narrative: Support to Tonga for preparedness and response to a potential Covid-19 outbreak in the region. Initial fund from Cabinet Paper approved 16/03/2020. Tonga requested support for its strategic preparedness and response plan for COVID-19, costed at a total NZ$3.2 million. This includes medical equipment and supplies, the renovation of a community health centre, PPE, transport and lab supplies. New Zealand will provide a NZD1 million untagged grant.
